name: Action Artifacts should not directly call a JSP page
description: For all action class (and parent classes) that are referenced in the struts-config.xml through the tag 'action-mapping' (in struts 1.x) or in struts.xml and its included files through the tag 'action' (in struts 2.x), list artifacts that refers to JSP pages will be reported.
output:
This report lists all Action artifacts calling a JSP pages.
It provides the following information:
- Artifact full name
- JSP page name
rationale:
- The Action classes are almost totally independent of the names of the presentation pages. The pages can be renamed (for example) during a redesign, with negligible impact on the Action classes themselves. If the names of the "next" pages were hard coded into the Action classes, all of these classes would also need to be modified.
- If Struts tags are used, then if a reference to a JSP page is directly made,  the behaviour of the Struts tags may become unpredictable. This because the ActionServlet or FilterDispatcher in Struts intercepts the request and provides appropriate attributes such as Message Resource Bundles and also FormBeans.
remediation: Use the action mapping table in struts configuration file.
total: Number of artifacts of classes and parent classes that are referenced as an action in the XML configuration file(s)

qualityStandards.name: Named Callable and Method Control Element with Layer-skipping Call
qualityStandards.description:
Objective
Avoid breaches of layered architecture principles due to layer-skipping references

Consequence
Software that does not follow the principles of layered architectures (such as strict partitioning and strict call hierarchy) decreases comprehensibility as well as simplicity to evolve the code

Measure Element
Number of instances where a named callable or method control element from a higher horizontal layer directly calls a named callable or method control element in a lower horizontal layer that is not adjacent to the upper layer making the call, as defined in a model of the application’s architectural layers (this excludes the vertical utility layers that can be referenced from any horizontal layer)
